title: BORING
content: This movie is long and boring. Don't get me wrong I do enjoy long movies, but this film is boring. I have only watched it once with friends almost anything is better than this movie.

title: Better than Ever. And Yet....
content: I had to read several other reviews to focus on what seems to be the important elements of this film. I'm grateful to the reviewers.I first saw the film at the age of 17, thought it was a great flick, and then pretty much forgot about it. I didn't understand the plot (what were the Brits and the French after, anyway?) but I did feel the gorgeous beauty of the photography and the locales, which formed a good basis for appreciating the film as I grew older.I have just seen the film again, in its socalled restored version. One technical word (as something of a technician myself): I say "socalled" because of the audio. Rarely have I seen a British film that gets the sound right. American films get it wonderfully right, with a sense of presence and clarity that the Brits somehow manage to mangle. That's a severe weakness of this film--even if it was restored.But getting to the heart of the matter.... My impression, in view of rave reviews of O'Toole and his acting, is that Sharif was the real star of the show (almost, that is). His character enters as a "cruel and barbarous" murderer but then slowly and convincingly evidences the humanity that makes his character virtually fall in love with the difficult Lawrence. In contrast, I found O'Toole's changes (not growth, but devolution) in the course of the film rather stilted, as if O'Toole lacked the experience and depth of his costar (and that's probably true). I can see how Sharif later turned into Zhivago, while I doubt that O'Toole could have handled such a role nearly as well.Lawrence of Arabia is about life, and it takes decades of life to appreciate its meaning (at least it did for me). As was said at the end of the film, young men make war and old men make the peace--and it must be so. The world is an old, old place, and our youthful dreams and aspirations and perceptions must eventually turn into the more sober and dejected outlooks of the mature. But that doesn't mean that older age is full of depression: appreciating the undulations of life and of our dreams is just part of the deal we get from God and the cosmos.Somehow, in some inexplicable way, I sense that this was Lean's message, and he delivered it well.

title: Rise and Fall of a Philosophical Warrior
content: The sandy front of World War I, set amongst the dunes and political turmoil of Syria, Egypt and Jordan, as seen by a cocksure British army officer with maybe a little bit of a messiah complex. A true epic, from the breath-stealing long shots of an unimaginably vast desert to the explosive, well-outfitted battle scenes, it lives up to the billing and then some. I was mesmerized by the photography in particular, which constantly discovers new ways to portray what could have been a rather redundant, flat, boring landscape. Truly beautiful, almost ruminative at times, with an appreciation for the artisanship of film.As for the plot, well... it's a bit slow. Particularly so in the nearly four-hour director's cut, which feels completely unnecessary. I've never seen the theatrical release, which is noted for being incomprehensible in places due to the awkward cuts, but it seems suspicious that half an hour or more couldn't have been lopped off somewhere to improve the pace. It's an exhausting watch, and not just because of the draining personal transformation we see in Lawrence himself. There's good material, of course, plenty of it. The hopeless inner squabble of an Arab population that's desperately close to the unified independence they seek. The protagonist's progression from philosophical humanist to enraged berzerker to shattered shell. We get plenty to think about, long after the credits have finally, mercifully rolled, but it's a marathon to reach that point.A Best Picture winner that's technically marvelous, thematically challenging and open-minded, but the ending left me feeling cold and there's really no excuse for it to run for as long as it does.

title: This movie insults my intelligence
content: Where to begin...oh yes This movie is like a piece of coal in a box covered with with beautiful wrapping. Looks great on the outside but when you open it, it is completely worthless and puts a frown on your face, exactly what I got with this movie.The director primarily decided that with movies, cinematography is best, everything else is secondary, especially dialog. There were very few lines in a movie of mammoth length, which is absolutely pathetic. I was not able to connect with either Lawrence, his friends or his enemies. The film became lazy hiding behind a beautiful shroud of desert and camels.Let me say this, movies are stories to be told. Cinematography is crucial to this, but if you add very little story to one, it becomes a hollow log that appeases to people who love vision only enjoyed by the eye. I am not from that crowd unfortunately.Here are some thing that could have made this a masterpiece:1. Less time filming treks through the desert...This got on quite a few people's nerve, despite the beautiful scenery we saw. We became bored and disconnected with Lawrence, like as if the long journey told an important story.2. Include more dialog...This is perhaps the worst part of the film, there wasn't any stuff to think about other than "I will do this job, yes". Through only Lawrence's actions, we could only determine that he fell in love with two Arabs going on a maverick's job to capture a Turkish hold, he killed a man who he saved earlier for murdering an Arab and was first reluctant but then enjoyed it? Never going into detail why. He gets abused by turks and...without any thought dialog other than a couple of expressions and the audience knowing he got abused, how he became so cold and angry?3. Try to be a bit more historically accurate if you don't care about story...This film was more like an amalgam of bits than a movie or history lesson. They didn't even include captions or dates to inform the audience how Britain came to be affaired with the campaign or Lawrence's past history.And to top it all off, a cheesy ending with a bunch of soldiers driving by in a truck singing on how they miss home, obviously saying that Lawrence will miss the middle-east, but we never became connected with why he will miss it so much.A huge disappointment of a movie. Yet a good example of cinematography, how long a movie should be (movies should be very long) and a good cast selection. But other than that it was more of a pretty picture with tons of money bursting out the frames.5/10

title: A Epic History Tale
content: After watching the movie, I feel pumped up inside after what I experience. The cinematography, the production design, the acting, the colors, and costumes were all beautifully strong and breathtaking to watch. I really cant get the "NO PRISONERS!" quote out of my head, it's keeps me wanting more. I would've ranked this movie a 9.5/10 if it was possible. The main leading actor and supporting actor should have won an Academy Award for their role, especially for Best Costume Design. I would give it 10/10, but I found myself comparing this film to Ben-Hur(1959). Although I find this movie extraordinary epic, I think Ben-Hur still tops as the definition of epic.Edit: You know what? Screw it! I can't stop thinking about the movie, I'm giving it a 10.

title: Best "War" Film Ever Made
content: As a retired military officer & both military & civilian diplomat, I'm especially partial toward "war" films without respect to their "attitude" about war. There are great anti-war & pro-war films, but the best films, regardless of their attitudes toward war are those films which can tell the truth about war without judgment. By that standard, I believe this to be the best war film ever made. It lays out the facts & lets the viewers draw their own conclusions. Moreover, this film has one other attribute necessary for a film to be great; it is entertaining! 😎

title: Every time I watch
content: This movie is spectacular. As I sit watching it now, I realize this movie could not be made again. We would see cgi, blue and green screens, etc. David Lean made the real thing. I will watch it again and again if only for the amazing cinematography, Peter O'Toole, and Omar Sharif. What an amazing pair!

title: Top 5 film of all time
content: Get lost in the adventure with Lawrence. The music and desert scenery are a match made in cinematic history. Both historic and historical. Fantastic action and storyline.

title: Irony
content: Apart the incredible scope and quality of this great movie, is one of the great ironies that I have encountered, the fact that this crazy man Lawrence lives through everything a man could go through, his eventual demise is on a joyride on a motorcycle.

title: At 1960; Great. At 2007; OK.
content: This wasn't a bad movie. Though I like faster action and dialog I could watch it to the end. Scenes were from time to time boring and this film wouldn't get as good review if it was published today. Music was nice and once I had to stop watching movie to get inspiration to guitar-riffs ;). Acting was OK with these lines the actors we're given. I could get only some messy ideas of the actors feelings. Battles were cool with all those camels and horses running around.. lot's of money gone to shooting fer sure.Scenery was really nice, whirlwinds and that fusion ball rising at the edge of desert.. Most people probably gave the rating 10 stars out of nostalgia. In the 60's there was probably not many better movies than this. Movie created some interest to know about the history aspects of Middle-East in early of 2000 century. Have Arabs really being so scattered? I have no idea of what really has been.Probably in right mood and bigger screen this could be better. If you are under 35 year old and don't like slower kind of films this could be waste of your time. For me, I think I'll watch mostly newer films from now on.. there's plenty of unseen yet.

title: Epic
content: Surely this is the greatest film ever made. Try and watch it in the cinema to experience it in full.

title: Shut those violins up!
content: It's a great film - of course it is. We all know that but it has the same musical refrain going throughout the movie from start to finish and if you happen not to particularly care for that refrain or overbearing violin in general, well.....it can blight one's enjoyment somewhat.

title: Timeless Legacy
content: "Lawrence of Arabia" truly shines with its grand scope, awe-inspiring landscapes, and meticulously designed cinematography. The vast expanse of the desert, monumental sand dunes, and breathtaking wide shots within the heart of the Arabian landscape are nothing short of mesmerizing.Peter O'Toole's portrayal of T. E. Lawrence is undeniably a pinnacle of his career. His magnetic presence, emotional depth, and ability to convey Lawrence's internal conflicts and contradictions leave a lasting impression.The film not only stands as a cinematic masterpiece but also holds immense historical significance, capturing a crucial era in the Middle East's history and shedding light on the intricacies of Western involvement.

title: Cinema at its finest
content: The film is a cinematic tour de force. The cinematography is extraordinary, especially considering the difficult conditions under which it was filmed. I have seen this film in 70 mm (which I high recommend doing), and I recently watched the 4k UHD, which gave me an even greater appreciation for how outstanding the cinematography is. The desert landscape provides an epic feel that's unsurpassed, aided by Maurice Jarre's magnificent score. David Lean's masterful direction guides us through it all, anchored by one of the greatest ever film performances by Peter O'Toole as the enigmatic, charismatic, yet troubled Lawrence. Highly recommended.

title: A epic masterpiece
content: This film is enthralling I was never bored watching it the way its shot the vast landscape the epic score this is a perfect film David lean was a genius to be able to direct this sprawling epic in the 60s with the limited technology I cant imagine how horrible it would have been to film in the desert

title: T. E. Lawrence British colonist biography.
content:
A timeless classic movie which has proved doubters for decades has been digitally remastered.
The movie show the real life story of a British military officer who rose the ranks due specially to his ambition in fighting for the cause of the Bedouin tribes against the Ottoman Empire.
The movie is filmed in separate locations, but brings the true character of the era together with great costume, and acting. The film is long at nearing 4 hours, with an intermission halfway in the style of the era the film is based on. Unfortunately the voices are a bit quiet at time during the film, but it doesn't back off the surreal story of the formation of the countries in the region specifically Jordan and Syria.

title: A great epic of cinema, full of remarkable scenes and that, even at almost four hours long, manages to captivate the viewer without becoming tiring
content: David Lean knew it would be a tremendous challenge to adapt the unlikely achievements of Thomas Edward Lawrence, one of the British Army's greatest soldiers during the Cairo campaigns against the Turks in World War I. Not only because of the great controversy surrounding his figure, but also because of the extremely difficult faithful representation of the events that occurred in Arabia between 1916 and 1918. The task of scripting the deeds of this very pertinent historical figure was the responsibility of Robert Bolt and Michael Wilson. Basing the entire narrative on the events described by T. E. Lawrence in his memoirs and notes, we have the creation of one of the most epic stories ever brought to the seventh art, despite its relatively simple approach. The merit of the simplicity of the story of Lawrence of Arabia lies in the point of interest that Lean and the scriptwriters wanted to focus on: the historical figure and nothing else, leaving aside any importance regarding the historical context of the War nor the disjointed situation of Arabia, which was not a Unified state, even more under strict control of the Ottoman Empire.During World War I, Lieutenant T. E. Lawrence (Peter O'Toole) is sent as an observer to the region of the Turkish Empire dominated by British troops. There, the English army works to convince the Arab prince Feisal (Alec Guinness) to abandon the desert and head to the coast, where the Arabs would be trained and armed. The prince resists the idea. Contrary to official guidance, Lawrence begins to work for the Arabs to stay. To show that victory is possible, he leads 50 Bedouins on a risky mission across the desert to take control of Aqaba, a strategic city held by the Turks.The mission is successful. Upon returning to England, Lawrence is promoted to colonel and obtains authorization from the command to lead the Arabs in the fight against the Turks. As in real life, Lawrence has spectacular victories. As he lives with the Arabs, he begins to respect their culture. He starts working with the British government so that the Arabs form an independent nation after the defeat of the Turks. He receives the guarantee that the Arab regions will not enter into the territorial partition between the victorious powers. With redoubled spirit, he takes on the role of liberator of the Arab people, transforming himself into the myth that he actually was. However, the soldier is unaware of the intricacies of politics. While he fights for Arab independence, the British government works for the victory of the interests of the great powers.In the first few minutes of the work, director David Lean can deceive us by showing Lawrence as an insubordinate idiot, a young man with a rebellious spirit, but this is soon dismantled when we discover the lieutenant's intellectual airs and great egocentrism. However, these characteristics become very useful when he interacts with the Bedouins, also revealing the anti-imperialist message of the first part of the film, in addition to praising the beneficial exchange of culture between peoples. In this way, we understand very well how Lawrence managed to unite several Bedouin tribes due to his interest, respect for others and thirst for knowledge, in addition to being free from prejudice. But there are several ironies for the first act of the feature, depriving the power that Lawrence believed to have when winning over his first friend who is soon murdered by Sherif Ali (Omar Sharif) who, in the future, ends up being a great companion of the protagonist.Lean thus advances the narrative by exhibiting rhapsodies of the barbarities committed by Bedouins addicted to violence as Lawrence tries to unify everyone to fight enemies. There is also a structure that is inspired by achievement in the dialogue so well presented in Akira Kurosawa's The Seven Samurai. That is, allies are never conquered by force, but through promises made by Lawrence's fierce language, which seeks to control everything and everyone, in a clear manifestation of desire for full control over men and nature. This is recurrent through the enigmatic images of small tornadoes observed on the horizon of the deserts and through the bad selfish choices that Lawrence assumes, always choosing the path with greater danger. The character wants to explore and become master of his own destiny - which makes the beginning of the film quite ironic. Incidentally, this point of "a man does what he wants" is the most exposed in very concentrated dialogues in the first half of the feature.Without worrying about compressing the narrative into the traditional two hours, David Lean takes the time he deems necessary to explore the desert, creating beautiful shots that take advantage of the sunrise and the exuberance of that sea of sand. Also counting on the dazzling photography of Freddie Young, the director creates a breathtaking look, which is confirmed even in the night scenes, skillfully lit by Young and which serve to create a contrast with the powerful light of the daytime scenes. The director is also competent in directing scenes of strong impact, such as the wars (which we will return to in a moment), and in intimate moments, such as Lawrence's slow walks through the desert. Also notice how the silence increases our anticipation seconds before the Bedouin Sherif Ali (Omar Sharif) appears on the distant horizon. When Lawrence rescues Gasim (I. S. Johar) in the desert, the triumphal trail indicates in advance that he saved the boy - Gasim still stars in another remarkable moment, when we discover that he is the murderer who must be executed by Lawrence, shortly after being killed. Saved by him. These two moments in which someone appears on the horizon demonstrate how Lean works with our sensations, making us share the harrowing experience of walking in the burning desert as if we were there, looking at the horizon without knowing if what we are seeing is real or just a mirage.While the first part of the feature is practically sublime, the second is slightly inferior due to the more stationary degree of Lawrence's narrative development, in addition to a great fragmentation via ellipses that can make everything too rushed. However, it is important to note that this does not negatively interfere with the experience, after all Lean manages to explore the dark side of Lawrence's mind a little more, marking his complete transformation. The character quickly enters into contradiction and, in order not to lose his feeling of grandiloquence, ends up doing the impossible to unite his allies again, resorting to superficial loyalties that make his leadership totally false, despite the British army still admiring his accomplishments. Soon, Lean builds two very impactful sequences showing Lawrence as one of wild passions, placing him as a false prophet, an unscrupulous military man and, worse, a war criminal responsible for one of the most visceral massacres of the confrontation.The last act epitomizes what makes Lawrence just a normal human, a flawed and very questionable hero and, worst of all, just an Englishman, an exogenous element who would never be able to lead the Arab people. Precisely for this reason, the end of the film is so powerful in contrasting the silent misery of one man with the happiness of another, completely ignorant of the pain of others. This question of whether or not to be British is practically supported by Lean and O'Toole's performance. Just notice how the character behaves when wearing the military clothes of his country, walking awkwardly and behaving childishly. However, when he receives the iconic white robes, Lean presents us with an intimate moment of the hero as he leaves his army to dance alone, feeling completely comfortable with the garments, believing himself to be a true Arab.Among the great scenes in "Lawrence of Arabia", it is worth highlighting the invasion of Aqaba, a breathtaking sequence, captured in a beautiful long shot by Lean that, in the end, reveals, through an elegant tracking shot, the cannon pointed towards the sea (and what a beautiful sea!), just as Lawrence had predicted. Another sensational battle takes place before arriving in Damascus, in a sequence that well illustrates the large number of extras used, demanding a lot of skill from the director in conducting the mise-en-scène - it is worth remembering that, contrary to what happens today, the battles do not used digital effects. And in addition to the striking war scenes, the melancholy death of a boy in quicksand deserves to be highlighted, which seems to serve to harden Lawrence's heart even more. An interesting curiosity: David Lean decided to show all the scenes from left to right. According to him, this was necessary to make clear Lawrence's tireless journey in the desert.Played by the charismatic Peter O'Toole, Lawrence initially emerges as a mysterious man, capable of captivating many people who barely knew him. Thin and slightly effeminate, O'Toole's Lawrence is a character full of nuances, who, contrary to his fragile appearance, slowly finds pleasure in killing his enemies. Despite being scared at first, Lawrence confirms this feeling in one of the battles, something that O'Toole conveys very well with his insane countenance during the conflict."Lawrence of Arabia" is a great epic that portrays the life of a complex character, full of qualities and defects like any human being. His leadership spirit and his charisma united the Arab peoples in the fight against the Turks, but he also underwent profound transformations in this trajectory, skillfully captured by the camera of David Lean - a specialist in large-scale productions and remarkable plastic beauty. The result is an exciting film, full of remarkable scenes and that, even at almost four hours long, manages to captivate the viewer without becoming tiring.

title: Truly a masterpiece on every count
content: Back in 62, my brother came home after watching "Lawrence of Arabia" and proclaimed to me that it was the best picture he had ever seen and will likely ever see. After hearing this, I had to see it! After watching it, I now find myself saying the very same thing to anyone who will listen. Every element that I use to judge a movie was met and surpassed leaving me astonished that I couldn't find a single flaw in the movie. Yes, it's a bit long but if you get caught up with it like my brother and I did, that doesn't bother you in the least. Every character was perfectly cast and delivered brilliantly. T.E. Lawrence was unknown to me prior to seeing this movie and it was great to get a glimpse of this character out of that era who was so different than his counterparts. If any other British Serving Officer had been given that assignment, history in that region would have turned out quite different. David Lean, so I understand, prepared himself for this project for several years because he wanted to get it right and oh my what a great job he did. To truly appreciate just how great this movie is, you have to view it many times and hone in on the dialogue and delivery.

title: Lawrence of Arabia
content: Lawrence of Arabia (1962) is one movie that you never get tired of rewatching. This film is based on the writings of T. E. Lawrence (a close friend of Virginia Woolf.) I have to confess I have not read any of his writings at the time of this review.This is the story of a British officer who led the Arab armies against the Turks in the Middle East during World War I from 1915 to 1918. However, the film itself is anything but basic. It is one of the classics still of our time.As the media gets better this film has been remastered and given the Blu-ray treatment. It may one day be a candidate for 4K. However, you will be so impressed with this film that the presentation media whether Blu-ray discs or streaming that the technical adjustments will be negligible to your viewing pleasure.I will not go into too much detail of the story as it is possible someone really has not seen this film before.The basic story is about a British officer that sees past the varied politics of the time and is able to find unique ways to help the Arabs create their own homeland whether they want it or not. However interesting the story is what makes this film unique is the stable of star actors, including of course Peter O'Toole, and extraordinary cinematography. The underlying music will stay with you for years.Many people have unique values as to what they would like to see in a movie. For me this film was excellent. I would suggest that no matter what your preference you do not pass up the chance to see "Lawrence of Arabia".Read about the real thing "Lawrence of Arabia: The Authorized Biography of T. E. Lawrence"

title: Not a great as I hoped and wanted it to be
content:
Story Summary: the story is about Thomas Edward Lawrence, dubbed
Lawrence of Arabia. A military Intelligence Officer from Great Britain, who united the Arab tried against the Turks during the WWIAnalysis: whilst not everyone will be familiar with the story of Lawrence of Arabia, the name surely will have some recognition. It's an epic tale that has been done justice enough in the 1962 version. One would hope that the story will not receive a remake or reboot. The beginning seems much stronger then the second and latter part.Dialogue: 6/10 while the script is good, sometimes it does feel a bit one-sided from the English perspective. A bit more Arab perspective would have given the story more body and thus more realistic dialogue. It's by no means bad, just not perfect. What is lacks sometimes is the feeling of being in Jordan when it comes to the conversation especially when the locals are talking with each other. The characters sometimes feels 2 dimensional, including LawrenceActing 7/10: the acting is well done. Theatrical, but that was where movie making was at the time. It does feel like the movie looses some focus towards the last hour. The main character is camp but kinda interesting too, but not likeable or relatable.Costume & Make up 7/10: most of the actors look like they belong in the movie. On the make up. The movie was produced in a different time. The bigger roles, like Prince Faisal and Auda Abu Tayi are played by non Arab actors.Local actors surely would have taken it to a different level. But the movie was made in a different time. That said, the effort to make English actors kind of look Arab is well done. What gives it away is not the look per se, but the mannerisms and voices. The whole film seems to have no female roles. There is an American journalist, who is a bit over the top and doesn't come across realistic.Camera, Visuals & Editing 8/10: Having been to the deserts in Jordan myself it looks good. The backdrops of Jordan and England are amazing. The movie has tried to film on as much places possible where Lawerence had been. For the other parts Spain and Morocco had been used. And it all blends amazing. Without revealing too much, but some of the shoots are stunning. Sometimes the footage is a bit dark, but this occurs during the night, so it is realistic although not always as clear to seen what is going on in detail. The interval goes on so long that I though some footage was missing.Special Effects 9/10: nothing bothers, which is surprising for such an old movie. It look all realistic.Music 8/10: very scenic and epic. Some more tribal Bedouin music would have made it perfect.Note on realism: As someone who has travelled through the Middle East, the depiction of the resentment between tribes is recognisable. The movie is a great attempt to be faithful to the memoir or Lawrence. Who seems to have acted in good faith. Whilst later the real world land borders were drawn by France and the UK, leading to some of the lasting tensions in the Middle East today. As mentioned before there's understanding for Arabic people who would not enjoy some depictions and aesthetics.Overall summary 6/10: the movie is clearly dated and has some interesting moments. Analysis of this movie being the best one of all time seems melancholic. The movie has many flaws especially the desert crossing scenes. The pace there is high and it lacks the absolute suffering of what it should have been in real life. The film does well to highlights issues and for that it can be praised. The depicting of Arabs is interesting, but far from always correct.

title: As Good as I Remember
content:
I saw Lawrence of Arabia in a movie theater when I was 8 years old. It's a part of my childhood, like The Longest Day, the Great Escape and Goldfinger. I'm pretty certain the Longest Day wouldn't hold up but the rest still fill a certain niche.
Lawrence of Arabia was on Turner Classic Movies recently. I picked it up about an hour in. To me, and my millennial son, it still holds up. Cinematography, story, personalities and great conflict. I wouldn't watch it every year but I find it mesmerizing. I have had Lawrence's memoirs in my study for 30 years. I read them initially because of the movie but it's great writing.

title: Sometimes history is to complex to capture in a movie, but this is a great attempt
content: I first watch this movie as a kid. It meant very little to me except it was "all the rage" with the grown ups, so I felt I needed to like it. Decades later I read several books on the real story of T.E. Lawrence, then re-watched the movie.Sometimes history is too complex to capture in a movie. Add political maneuvering, several millennia of cultures, various traditions, and trying to explain the world Lawrence found himself in becomes impossible.So, don't over think this movie. Watch it for what it is; an opinionated view of pre WWI Middle East history, and you'll be much better off.The big appeal and success of this movie is O'Toole's performance. It's outstanding! And, if it weren't for the fact this movie bogs down and is a bit too long for it's own good, I'd have given this movie a higher rating.Despite it's shortcomings, this movie does a lot to explain the situation the Middle East, even today. And, it prompted me to read history. I'd say that's a good reason for me to recommend this movie.

title: Iconic picture for the ages
content: This acclaimed film by equally acclaimed director David Lean needs to introduction, as it is often considered one of the best and most revolutionary movies in Hollywood history - and with good reason, of course.It is simply an epic, incredibly sharp script and beautiful cinematography that feels very characteristic of Lean's style. The actors all do an incredible job, and are of course all very established.It is simply a classic that resonates on every level, and a masterpiece in terms of filmmaking. Beautifully cinematographied, cut and edited, and revolutionary shooting.Of course very much recommended for any lover of film, though I would expect most have seen it already!

title: stunning film - must see
content: If ever a movie earned the definition 'epic', then 'Lawrence Of Arabia' is it. In an age when sumptuous set-pieces can be effortlessly conjured-up by computer programmers, this truly authentic feast of cinematic vision still possesses the power to blow your mind. This is the real thing. The wide-sweeping vistas of desert wilderness are not special-effects; they are REAL. And they look real. Long views, sweeping pans and takes sustained over minutes are realised with a clarity, colour and vividness that absolutely melt your heart. That imagery is a more believable conduit to this complex man's evolving obsession with Arabia than the narrative itself.Every scene is a breathtaking study in light and colour, character and dialogue. Every second is worth seeing and every word worth hearing. And its theme music is as iconic as the man himself.The inimitable Peter O'Toole with his blonde hair, steely-blue eyes, haunting expressions and mood swings, commands your attention in every take. His Lawrence is a man swallowed up by a personal sense of destiny, striding between his cynical and prosaic taskmasters and a doomed belief in what might be achieved with superhuman effort. Omar Sharif never played a better role as foil to his capricious hero. Unusually, there are no leading ladies. And they're certainly not needed. A love interest would have cheapened the entire presentation. Here is a story about the romance of time and place. As that other great Arabian traveller and admirer of the ideal - Wilfred Thessiger - once remarked; "women spoil everything".This is a long movie. Those with short attention-spans raised upon sausage-machine editing are doomed to find it dull, tedious, boring, slow and all of the other criticisms that fall from the lips of a generation accustomed to x-box action sequencing. But if you are blessed with a longer vintage, then Lean's masterpiece will swallow you up as surely as the desert itself.

title: Watchable but...
content: ...for all the praise of O'Toole's performance, I'm not entirely sure what he was going for. There's a fine line between a portrayal that reveals a character in all their nuances and contradictions, and one where we murmur "why, aren't we the mysterious fellow." Sometimes I think that line was crossed.I won't engage any of the anachronistic criticisms I see here. The film was made in a different time with different viewer expectations than those of our own. Deal with it. At the same time, yeah, the attitudes toward "the natives" are a bit much at points.I do feel sorry for the families of those who come off somewhat badly and were in real life much better people than the film allows. As often, it's done to set up the lead actor in opposition to second-rate people and a harsh environment that must be overcome, when either or both were actually more benign than shown. But Hollywood license isn't totally without merit.

title: Movie focused on the character development
content:
Movie focused on the character development. Shows how movies were different back in the days. Resemble more of a book or great novel perspective.-
But I must explain to you how all this mistaken idea of denouncing pleasure and praising pain was born and I will give you a complete account of the system, and expound the actual teachings of the great explorer of the truth, the master-builder of human happiness. No one rejects, dislikes, or avoids pleasure itself, because it is pleasure, but because those who do not know how to pursue pleasure rationally encounter consequences that are extremely painful. Nor again is there anyone who loves or pursues or desires to obtain pain of itself, because it is pain, but because occasionally circumstances occur in which toil and pain can procure him some great pleasure. To take a trivial example, which of us ever undertakes laborious physical exercise, except to obtain some advantage from it? But who has any right to find fault with a man who chooses to enjoy a pleasure that has no annoying consequences, or one who avoids a pain that produces no resultant pleasure? On the other hand, we denounce with righteous indignation and dislike men who are so beguiled and demoralized by the charms of pleasure of the moment, so blinded by desire, that they cannot foresee.

title: Beautifully shot, decent acting -- but WAY too long
content: Unlike the movie, I'll make it quick:* Pluses: beautiful cinematography, most of the actors did a good job* Minus (a BIG one): it is WAY too long. You could have halved the running time and have plenty of room for telling the exact same story. I forgot names and plot points DURING the movie, that's not supposed to happen! Hell, I forgot the name of my first pet and my own address during the movie too. It was that long, and that boring.Like a lot of other old classic movies, I get why it was popular or groundbreaking when it first came out. But it's time to let this dusty thing fall of the "best movies" lists.Oh, and just as an aside; there are almost no women in this marathon of a movie, and none that speak. The only women I could spot at all were some nurses in the background of a hospital shot (and their faces weren't even visible).

title: The endless epic
content: The voyage of a conqueror starts with an affection and curiosity towards a place. T. E Lawrence's s story is that of a conqueror and his voyage starts in the desert of Arabia.Lawrence of Arabia Is a fascinating epic that can be viewed in more than one way. The story starts with T. E Lawrence played by Peter O. Toole, dying and the following story is then told as a flashback. The story that follows is that of the middle eastern campaign during WWI and we follow Lawrence on his epic adventure to help the Arabs fight against the Turkish and gain their freedom.As we follow Lawrence through his journey, he becomes somewhat corrupted as his humanity is tested several times during the movie. Lawrence goes from a passive being afraid of violence, to a being that ravishes in it. His character arc still to this day says a lot about how once's surroundings can affect your mentality and how your mentality and psyche can become corrupted. We even get a scene in this movie where Lawrence asks the general to be reassigned as he fears his mind is being lost and therefore him becoming a dangerous person.The dialog in this film is unusual for its time, given that many films from that period have a dialog filled with references that becomes dated. The references and dialog in this film appears in many ways modern, and it adds so much to the film. The moral of this story and Lawrence's moral code is: "Nothing is written" and "your fate is not determined".When it comes to epics, this alongside "2001 a space odyssey" stands as a somewhat definition of the genre, and yet they are widely different. This movie has a linear structure in the way it is told, and it is therefore an easy experience to follow the plot, even though the duration of the film is very long. Lawrence of Arabia features some truly magnificent shots all filmed in 70mm Panavision which makes every scene look like a work of art. The locations used in the film is easily one of the best in movie history and they are so memorable.With a straightforward plot and beautiful camerawork, the cinematography and music certainly do not let the film down. When it comes to great cinematography this movie is in its own league and features some top of the shelf camera work. Every scene is as I said a piece of art and the director David Lean went to great length, to make them that way. You get beautifully shot scenes of sunrises and astonishing scenes of the dunes featuring mirages. The scene in which Sherif Ali appears in the distance almost as if he is sailing on illusionary water is one that stands out among a frighting number of great scenes.You can't review this masterpiece without mentioning its musical score. This film won a much-deserved Oscar for its score, and it is one of the best in movie history. The melody is of a simple nature, yet it's almost as it is tailored to fit each scene specifically. Maurice Jarre composed the score, and he truly made a score fit for the masterpiece that is the movie itself.While I understand that watching a 3 hour and 40-minute film may seem like a daunting task, this film is nothing other than a pleasant viewing all together. There is so much to take away from this movie and I could talk for literal days about it. I enjoyed the viewing of this film thoroughly and I highly recommend it.My rating: 95/100.

title: The Epic of all Epics
content:
Everything have been said about this godpiece.
David Lean and his cinematographer, Fred A. Young, have given us something really spectacular to look at; the desert, in all its austerity and grandeur, is the star.

title: A masterclass in storytelling, however..
content: A Masterclass In Storytelling, but..First, let me just say I thought the cinematography was beautiful. Absolutely stunning. The acting was fantastic, the storytelling was majestic, the culture clashes, the brutal violence, the gorgeous and completely unforgiving lands.. All brilliant!That being said. This picture is often described as "one of the best films of all time". No.. There, I said it!As I said the acting was top class. My issue was Peter O'Toole's portrayal of T. E. Lawrence. Often I felt the performance was just too effeminate to be believable. I mean, hinting at homosexuality is one thing but he was being portrayed as the most camp and flamboyant man in documented history. I find it hard to believe these hard men would've followed and taken orders from someone if he was truly prancing and floating around quite like that.Also, the run time of nearly 4 hours was just too long.

title: A saga of epic proportions..
content: "Lawrence of Arabia" had been on my must-watch movies list for a long time. There was so much I had heard and read about it. A lot had been written about this epic saga of T.E. Lawrence as being one of the greatest and most influential films of all time, revered by many great directors including Martin Scorsese.I finally got a chance to see it recently, and considering all the good things I had heard about it, I must admit that my expectations were quite high."Lawrence of Arabia" tells the story of Lt. Colonel T.E. Lawrence, focussing on his war experiences in Arabia during World War I. A topic of such vast proportions needed an equally ambitious project to pull it off, and indeed, the filmmakers have put in a lot of efforts in painting this huge canvas and achieving what they'd set out to. Peter O'Toole plays the eponymous T.E. Lawrence. The film starts out with the accidental death of T.E. Lawrence in the present. The film then flashes back to narrate the story of how Lawrence was sent on a mission to evaluate the situation in Arabia, pertaining to Prince Faisal and his revolt against the Ottoman Turks.Rest of the film then shows Lawrence's own involvement in leading the Arabs in the battle against Turks. So needless to say, you are presented with extravagant battle scenes, and long, never-ending desert treks, Lawrence's new-found friendships, his emotional ups and downs and some difficult choices that he is presented with. The director heavily indulges in showing off the beautifully shot desert landscapes (with the excellent Super Panavision 70 cinematography by Freddie Young)."Lawrence of Arabia" lived up to my expectations during most of its long running time. In fact a lot more during the first two hours of the film. But something happened in the final act. Somehow the whole film seemed to go a bit awry and disoriented for some reasons which I am finding difficult to put in words. Suffice to say that it wasn't the overwhelming experience I thought it would be. For one, I think the film could have easily been cut short. A lot of time has been spent on desert treks and their long journeys through it. Yes, these scenes do require detail to show the hardships these men must've faced while crossing those perilous desert lands. But I somehow feel the director went too far in his attempt. So much so that the events taking place in the final 30-45 minutes seem too abrupt and disconnected.There have been films as long as this and longer, but they have enough substance to fill those long hours. There are sufficient examples ('The Godfather Part II', 'Schindler's List', 'Seven Samurai' to name a few). "Lawrence of Arabia" has enough substance, yes, but a running time of 216 minutes, was simply not necessary.That aside, the film, of course has plenty of plusses: As mentioned earlier, Freddie Young's cinematography is superb, so is Maurice Jarre's inspirational score. David Lean does a great job in directing this script by Robert Bolt and Michael Wilson, but falls a little short of expectations in terms of distribution of the content. Nonetheless, this was in itself a magnificent, ambitious project and a difficult one at that, so it is not fair to nitpick too much.The cast: Peter O'Toole's performance is widely talked about. For me, frankly it was somewhat inconsistent. Not to take away any merits from the Legendary actor's acting talent. He was, in fact, great in some scenes. But I was slightly put off by the sometimes nervous, sometimes excessively confident behaviour. Then there were some scenes in which he went way over the top in displaying his emotions. Maybe it was the director who wanted O'Toole to act like that and O'Toole gave the director what he wanted.The supporting cast is great, especially Omar Sharif, Anthony Quinn and Alec Guiness. I had seen Anthony Quinn in Fellini's "La Strada" earlier and it was great to see him display such versatility.All said, "Lawrence of Arabia" is a great film, but falls a tad short of being a masterpiece in my book.However, it definitely deserves to be watched at least once by any serious lover of cinema.

title: Every Grain of Sand
content: David Lean is probably the most famous English movie director of all time (with the possible exception of Alfred Hitchcock). Initially he made small, tidy pictures from English classics, often co-directed with playwright-performer Noel Coward. And then, in an unlikely partnership with producer Sam Spiegel, he became an international star. His film "The Bridge on the River Kwai" became a worldwide success.Five years later, the two men decided to collaborate again. This time over "Lawrence of Arabia", which Sam Spiegel had bought the rights to a few years earlier. However, the film was close to not being made at all. Spiegel didn't think the unknown Peter O'Toole was the right man for the lead in such a large production. It was only after having seen O'Toole's screen test that the producer gave him the thumbs up.The film takes place during World War I. It describes how Thomas Lawrence, a young English officer, participates in the Arab revolt against the Turks. His bravery soon makes him a respected leader.Due to David Lean's obsession with details, the making of the movie became problematic right from the start. The first, seemingly simple scene, where O'Toole is riding through the desert on his camel, took a month to shoot. And things weren't made easier by the fact that Lean used a newly invented Super Panavision camera so heavy that the film crew had to mount it on a small locomotive to be able to move it.However, the film was a great success, at home and internationally. "Lawrence of Arabia" filled cinemas in London and Madrid for over a year. It also won Oscars in seven different categories, one of which went to Spiegel (as producer) and one to Lean (director). But sadly, they had a terrible falling out in the following years. After David Lean accused Sam Spiegel of grabbing too large a share of the movie's profit, the two men never spoke to each other again.

title: Shameless windbag
content:
O'toole is a windbag, one of those detestable snobs who seems to revel in hearing his own voice.

title: GREAT
content: Was good to see this on Netflix where I watched it twice. One of the best movies ever made and an exceptional performance from new comer Peter O'Toole. David Lean was one of the greatest directors of his time. Beautifully made and an excellent supporting cast. title: A visual Epic!
content: When you remember Lawrence of Arabia, it is less about the dialogue, the characters, the cinematography or the toll of war on a man, although individually taken, any of them could be a sufficient conversation in itself. When you remember Lawrence of Arabia, you remember the experience, as all the different things I mentioned above come together to make a brilliant movie.Nearly a 4 hour long movie, this is one of those few films you could watch again and again and again and still be dwarfed by the vastness of its vision.

title: A Grand Epic with Stunning Visuals, Elevated by Omar Sharif's Presence
content: Lawrence of Arabia is undeniably one of the most visually breathtaking films ever made, a cinematic achievement that captures the vast beauty of the desert and the complexities of war and identity. David Lean's direction is masterful, and Peter O'Toole delivers an iconic performance as T. E. Lawrence.However, what truly elevates the film is Omar Sharif's commanding presence. His portrayal of Sherif Ali is a testament to his talent and charisma, making him one of the greatest Egyptian actors to leave a mark on Hollywood. From his unforgettable entrance in the desert to his layered performance, Sharif adds depth, nobility, and emotional weight to the story. His chemistry with O'Toole is compelling, making their dynamic one of the film's strongest aspects.While the film's length and pacing may feel overwhelming at times, its grandeur, cinematography, and historical depth make it a classic worth experiencing.A visually stunning epic that showcases Omar Sharif's undeniable talent and Hollywood presence, even if its pacing can be demanding.

title: "...Nothing is written"
content: What a gigantic cinematic boom Lawrence of Arabia makes. It's an epic that's controlled by one of the most assured and basically visionary directors that the material could have asked for. And it leaves its final thirty minutes not with a totally triumphant hero, but one with more conflicts and despair than one might expect. Not that I would really expect a lot of Lawrence of Arabia on total fact, even as it is based on T.E. Lawrence's writings. Like with any other given number of biopics, we're given the 'character' of Lawrence, not the full-on man himself. And in Lean's ultra-masculine, heroic take on the man, it's got enough great scenes to knock others in other films out of the park.Why then did I feel as if I hadn't seen one of the very greatest films ever made? It's definitely not that i can't understand why some would say it so, as it contains that great need to tell a story that's worth telling (in the context it's presented), and with a cast of characters acted with the most finite of professionalism and passion. It's also the sort of picture, rarely made today it seems, that without a doubt is one of those meant to be seen on the big screen- practically all of the images captured by Lean and his crew out in that desert make a very convincing kind of metaphor for the picture, as man, no matter how much he ambitions or seeks out this or that or might think he is invincible for a little while, is quite small when seen in the 'grander scheme of things.'But like some other epic works I can think of, like Alexander Nevsky (albeit its short length I think of it in epic terms), or even more contemporary the Lord of the Rings, amid such a brave and undaunted work of superior craftsmanship there are some things that, subjectively, aren't totally in synch for me. One of those, chiefly, is Peter O'Toole's performance. It was his first big starring performance, and it's sort of mixed for me how I view him in this character. He ends up, by virtue of his own talents, being terrific in many scenes, like when he has to come to a fate with the same man he previously had saved en-route to Ackaba, or when he returns back to Cairo to tell of his "impossible" victory.Even the last half hour or so that I mentioned before is better than expected, as we see more of an opening up of the sort of mythical representation of the character of Lawrence. But for a lot of it I just didn't really see him as much as a conflicted and ambiguous legend as I did as a, well, light-voiced British guy. In some scenes I almost felt as if it was someone still coming to terms with playing such a larger-than-life guy, and with the same attitude and mannerisms of someone doing (not to put him down too much but) lesser-ring theater. He's actually kind of 'neat' for the role, and unfortunately in comparison with his counterparts he's not one of the most notable parts even as Lawrence himself is the main juice of the picture.Meanwhile, other actors get their time on screen wonderfully, with Shariff probably never (or rarely) better as Sheriff Ali, as he and Lawrence have the most fascinating connection of all. Quinn is quite good, if a little hammy (as to be expected) as the Tayi, the rival warrior who first wants gold and then goes along with what Lawrence might have in mind. It's always great to see Guiness with such control and nuance with a character who gets such limited time when compared with the other supporting players. They're all pit in a story that has a great energy in the first half, as Lawrence goes from shuttered in soldier to a near prophet for a whole mass of Arabs by crossing a desert deemed uncrossable, and storming a city thought to have been impossible to take. Then, as he continues military campaigning in part two however, things start to change, if maybe a little too fast one might think following his tense scene with Jose Ferrer's character.And all the while this is put to Lean, with his DP Freddie Young, in creating a larger-than-life atmosphere for a man who has highs and lows of how his perception goes, including to himself. A lot of times as Lawrence and/or his men went across the desert, or a character looked into the near abyss of sands, it was nearing being too picturesque, as if the style vied to overtake the substance. But Lean is always in service of the story, and the deliberate but wise screenplay. Not matter how grandiose Lean can get, he shoots with a sense of some conviction. One more note that makes Lawrence of Arabia quite worthwhile is the musical score, the kind that you rarely hear in big studio pictures with the exceptions of maybe John Williams or Howard Shore. Of all the Oscars given out to this film, the only one probably more deserved after Lean was for Jarre's compositions, which compliment the images and add just the right touches of emphasis.It's not un-probable that I could come back to Lawrence of Arabia some years from now and maybe even find it greater, even more towering an achievement of using insane lots of money to add flesh and bones to adapting history onto celluloid. For sure, if it ever does get re-released again, I probably would even check it out. That I might not put it so high in my favorite films though is also hard to deny: it is, like Lawrence, "not perfect". But it is still quite a ride getting through it all.

title: An hour too long
content: This movie is well made and I can see how there are people who love this movie. But this film is one hour too long. My problem is not with length. I liked both the godfather parts one and two and I didn't feel they were too long. But this movie could have been told in two and a half hours. The March through the desert could have been 30 minutes shorter, and every scene is about two minutes too long. That being said the acting is very good, and it was good to see Alec Guiness in something that wasn't star wars. There was just too much wasted time in this film for me to give it any better than 7/10.

content: its shocking really that a piece of art that you find so moving and inspiring would be seen as "boring" or "to long" by others...as i read over some of the posts regarding lawrence of arabia i am just amazed that anyone could look negatively at this work...beyond the incredible scale, exotic locations and the fact it is a cinematic marvel it is in my opinion one of the finest stories ever put to film...the characters have wonderful depth and are very well portrayed across the board...the pacing is absolutely perfect...and it goes with out saying the cinematography is breathtaking...how anyone could find this boring is just astounding....it is without a doubt one of my fav movies ever....and for the idiot that said peter o'toole comes off as feminine it is speculated that lawrence was in fact homosexual don't worry i hear there making another sequel to the fast and the furious
